results.title: The Environmental revolution
results.creator_credit: John Angier, Carol Lynn Dornbrand, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This introductory episode examines the two major revolutions that have changed how human societies use resources - the agricultural and industrial revolutions. It then suggests that a third revolution - a global awareness of human impacts - is beginning to cause equally far-reaching changes in society. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: The Environment: garbage
results.brief_description: Uses a montage of garbage cans, music and images, with no narration, to reveal the many kinds of garbage and the need to be aware of the problem. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: The Environment game
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Michael Blakstad
results.brief_description: Technological progress, essential to the economy of an industrial nation, must be subject to checks and controls to prevent the destruction of landscapes and pollution of the quality of life. Using schoolchildren to represent the various interests concerned, the film debates the problems, with visits to various locations to illustrate the issues at stake.

results.title: The Environment (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of the Open Learning Economics course looks at the way the international economic community is tackling the issue of environmental protection. Since the late 1970s there has been a growing concern, especially by communities in wealthier nations, over the high environmental cost of unrestricted economic development. Developing countries, however, have argued that trade restrictions predicated on environmental law offer unfair economic advantages to richer nations. In the first half of the program we look at the example of the Mexican tuna industry which has come under fire because of the destruction of dolphin life. However when the United States attempted to place an embargo on Mexican tuna, the General Agreement on Tarrifs and Trade (GATT) ruled that this was contrary to the principles of Free Trade. In the second half we look at the destruction of Europe’s Rhine River by industrial pollution. The panel of economists examining both issues discuss some of the implications for trade if environmental law becomes institutionalised in the global economy.

results.title: The Entity
results.creator_credit: American Cinema Productions, Pelleport Investors, Harold Schneider and Sidney J. Furie
results.brief_description: This horror/haunted house/poltergeist movie is based on a true story of a woman who was harassed by inexplicable forces. Carla Moran (Barbara Hershey) is a caring mother who lives with her children, when she is repeatedly and brutally raped by an unseen entity, and besieged by other inconceivable events that petrify her. Carla is increasingly isolated (even ridiculed) for her experiences, which rack her emotionally and physically. When she seeks professional help, a team of psychiatrists study Carla’s situation seeking to unravel the source of her terror. Some sceptics in the team believe it to be female hysteria even insanity, but one kindly doctor, Phil Schneidermann (Ron Silver) is convinced of her sincerity and is determined to aid her plight with science and a parapsychological approach. At times genuinely terrifying, this film is somewhat dated, particularly in the special effects department, but interestingly was released just a year before Spielberg’s hugely successful “Poltergeist”, with which it shares many major themes. Hershey puts in a fine performance as an imperilled woman whose ordinary (if bleak) life is put under siege by forces beyond her comprehension. Although the film takes a somewhat dissatisfying turn mid-way through, it remains an interesting example of a science versus spirit movie and should prove a boon to horror buffs.

results.title: The Entertainer
results.creator_credit: Robert Stigwood Organisation, Persky-Bright Productions, Beryl Vertue, Marvin Hamlisch and Donald Wrye
results.brief_description: Coping with constant failures, down and almost out comedian Archie Rice (jack Lemmon) lives with his family and his famous retired father Billy (Ray Bolger). He dreams of the day he will be a star. Cast also includes Sada thompson, Tyne Daly, Michael Cristofer. From the play by John Osborne with music by Marvin Hamlisch.

results.title: The Enormous turnip
results.creator_credit: Lorne Magory, Jenny Reeks, Pickwick Video and Ladybird
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Read it yourself”.
Nerys Hughes presents the well-known children’s story, “The Enormous Turnip”. An old man planted some turnip seeds, but one of the seeds grows and grows, till it is so enormous no one could harvest it - at least, not until help came. The video comes with the picture book of the same story so young viewers can both watch and read the story. The video concludes with a talk on turnips, a song about planting turnips and some related gardening and craft activities for children.

results.title: The Enormous Crocodile
results.brief_description: When the Enormous Crocodile boasts that he is going to eat a child for his lunch the other jungle animals decide to foil his dastardly plot. Children will delight in the exploits of Humpy Rumpy, Muggle Wump and the Roly-Poly bird. The animation is based on the original illustrations of Quentin Blake for another of Roald Dahl’s entertaining moral tales.

results.title: The Enigma of Kaspar Hauser = Jeder fur sich und Gott gegen alle
results.creator_credit: Werner Herzog Filmproduktion, Walter Saxer and Werner Herzog
results.brief_description: Regarded as Herzog’s finest film, “The Enigma of Kasper Hauser” is based on a true story about a 19th Century genius. His origins shrouded in mystery, Kasper Hauser was found wandering the streets of Nuremberg in 1820. Without speech, nor any sign of parentage, Hauser immediately becomes the object of scrutiny from the town authorities. After learning to talk he tells of living in a cellar, displaying no signs of having had any contact with other human beings since childhood. In his attempts to adjust to adult life, he reveals a highly advanced intelligence and alternative, almost prophetic, vision. Herzog demonstrates his fascination with misfits, and as the story develops, the confrontation between innocence and corruption intensifies. Cast includes Bruno S, Walter Ladengast and Brigitte Mira. In German with English subtitles.
